awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Offshore Wind Energy Center for Infrastructure Resilience, Control, Innovation, and Transmission (OWE-CIRCIT)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program.  Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

The Offshore Wind Energy (OWE) industry in Europe is booming, and has reduced electricity generation costs to less than $0.10 per kWh. The U.S. OWE resource is enormous, and could provide 10-20 times the national need for electricity. The U.S. is just starting to develop this resource, does not yet have an industrial supply chain for OWE, and there are unique U.S. challenges because of hurricanes, complex seabed conditions, and grid integration. In order to address these challenges, and to design resilient and cost-effective heavy OWE infrastructure (e.g., structures, transmission system), a convergent approach is needed. Failure for the U.S. to take this approach, to plan accordingly, to maximize continuous learning, and to take disruption actions when needed, would be a hugely missed opportunity for society to benefit from the breadth of U.S. expertise and knowhow, and to make technological advancements that have broad applications. 

This ERC planning grant project will bring together those with relevant expertise in OWE from several engineering disciplines, fields of science, the national laboratories, state and federal resource management agencies, industrial stakeholders, and developers; as well as those from affected coastal communities. This group will design a data-driven multi-disciplinary system-level framework that identifies where advances are needed to build a resilient infrastructure (blades, turbine, support structure, transmission grid, standards, and models) that would enable a large and responsible level of OWE to be harvested. The technical areas to be integrated together in this frame will include but are not limited to metocean characterization (wind, waves, currents), composite materials, aerodynamic modeling, geo-engineering parameters, stability, fatigue, corrosion, inspection, control, renewable energy integration, social acceptance of OWE development, and impact on marine and coastal ecosystems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Outcome of The Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Offshore Wind Energy Center for Infrastructure Resilience, Control, Innovation, and Transmission (OWE-CIRCIT).

The goal of the CIRCIT ERC was to determine the state-of-the-art, challenges, and potential solutions for how to advance many key aspects of the development and operation of offshore wind energy farms within a systems-level framework. The PIs on this award, and others, did submit a preproposal to the NSF ERC program, but this was not selected for the submission of a full proposal. Regardless, significant benefit was and continues to be realized from the support provided by NSF because of the many discussions, relationships, ideas, and proposals that were enabled by this support. As outlined in the full report, this included several projects funded by the U.S. Department of Energy, U.S. Department of the Interior, NSF, and State clean energy organizations. These awards covered many of the topics that were central to the OWE-CIRCIT planning grant award, including:

A study of the fatigue design and behavior of both steel and concrete support structures (i.e. foundations and towers) for offshore wind turbines.

A comparative assessment of the effectiveness of different corrosion protection systems (coatings and cathodic protection) on the longevity of offshore wind support structures.

An assessment of how offshore wind energy infrastructure impacts the marine ecosystem, and habitats. This involved both paper and field studies.

An NSF-GOALI project looking at seabed ring anchors that support multi-directional loadings.

An NSF-DUE project to better the instruction in power systems.

This project also contributed to the compression of 6 papers and 2 theses.

This NSF ERC planning grant strengthened and broadened the understanding of each member of the funding research team, as well as many others engaged in this project and initiatives that stemmed from this award. This group continue to work together in ongoing research, educational initiatives, and the pursuit of projects from a variety of sources to advance the responsible design of offshore wind energy farms. The original motivation for the ERC planning grant remains, and is repeated below to express the continuing beliefs and ambitions of the research team.

The intended ERC will generate beneficial societal impacts by enabling coordinated development of the U.S. offshore wind energy (OWE) resource in a way that maximizes public benefits and differs from the European model and the current path of U.S. OWE. In both of those cases, a project-by-project approach to planning, design, and management is being used on an ad hoc basis. The benefits of OWE-CIRCIT to society include enabling provision of a clean, low cost, resilient, and secure energy supply; and the development of fundamental and enabling knowledge and technology in convergent areas of engineering, social science, and risk-based planning and management that will be applicable to other large scale distributed systems.
